telescope of the spectral apparatus, <s>dis<\s>[re]solved 
into dark lines. The number of such dark 
lines of one of the brightest bands (of the 8th
band, we always count from the red to the 
violet) was found to be 34, or nearly so.
Their mutual distance is nearly the same 
but their darkness decreas<s>ing<\s>[es] towards the 
least refracted limit of each channeled band.
Hence we concluded, the breadth of the 
band h<s>e<\s>aving been measured, that the an
gular distance of two contiguous shading 
lines <s>be<\s> [was] nearly equal to the distance of 
the two sodium-lines. The breadth of the 
channeled bands varies, but the character
of all is absolutely the same; only if 
foreign bright lines, like those of hydrogen 
are simultaneously seen, it becomes slightly 
disturbed. We may distinguish 17 bands 
of this description, the first three are smaller 
ones, the 4th is traversed by H[beta] the 11th 
by H[gamma]. We denote by H[alpha], H[beta] and H[gamma] the 
three bright lines of the spectrum 
of Hydrogen, the red, the bluish green 
and the violet one. See (57).
At the violet extremity the light 
is very faint.
17. The bands of the less refracted part of 
the spectrum are all of nearly the same 
breadth but smaller than those just described 
and of quite a different appearance. Making
use of only <s>one<\s> [a] single prism and of a small 
magnifying power we count 18 such 
bands, starting from the extreme red 
and extending to the greenish yellow, where 
they are bounded by a dark space. H[alpha] falls
